args_preview.learning: When using dataclasses with enums and json.dump(), asdict() preserves enum objects which json.dump() cannot serialize. Always convert enums to their .value explicitly after asdict() before JSON serialization. The TypeError raised mid-write causes truncated/corrupt JSON files.

When sys.path.insert(0, path) is used at startup, imports will load modules from that path first, even if newer versions exist elsewhere. This is by design but can cause confusion during debugging when local edits don't seem to take effect.

args_preview.outcome: Found root cause: asdict() preserves enum objects, json.dump() fails mid-write causing truncated files. Fixed by adding data['type'] = candidate.type.value. Committed 707804b, all tests pass.
args_preview.task: Debug and fix promotion compactor enum serialization bug

args_preview.learning: When building a dashboard to visualize Duro data, the project should live inside Duro's allowed workspace (C:\Users\sibag\.agent\) for full access. The Duro MCP server is stdio-based with no HTTP API, so a FastAPI wrapper is needed to expose data to web frontends. The wrapper should import ArtifactIndex directly from duro-mcp for database queries and use read-only SQLite access to avoid lock contention with the main MCP server.

For industrial/terminal UI design: use dark backgrounds (#0C0C0C), neon green accents (#00FF88), JetBrains Mono for body text, Space Grotesk for headlines, zero corner radius, bracket notation for status ([OK], [ACTIVE]), and code-style naming (TOTAL_ARTIFACTS). This aesthetic matches the Duro identity as a command-center style agent system.

args_preview.outcome: Created complete dashboard design at x:47800 in drills.pen with: sidebar (navigation + system status), header (title + heartbeat + search), 4 metric cards, activity feed, memory browser. Industrial terminal aesthetic with neon green accents.
args_preview.task: Design Duro Dashboard UI in Pencil

Backend verified at localhost:8001, frontend builds and runs on localhost:5173.

args_preview.learning: Duro's SQLite database schema does NOT have a 'data' column in the artifacts table. Artifact content is stored in separate JSON files referenced by 'file_path'. When building queries, use file_path to read full artifact data.
When uvicorn --reload isn't picking up changes to router files, restart the server completely without --reload flag first to verify changes work, then add --reload back.

args_preview.learning: When restarting uvicorn server on Windows, old processes may persist even after taskkill. Use PowerShell's Stop-Process with -Force flag for reliable process termination. Also verify port is free with netstat before starting new server - multiple processes can bind to same port on different interfaces (0.0.0.0 vs 127.0.0.1).

args_preview.learning: FastAPI router changes require full server restart even with --reload flag if the router file is new. The file watcher may not detect new files in subdirectories. Clear __pycache__ and kill all Python processes to ensure clean state.

args_preview.learning: For Duro Dashboard Insights feature: v1 approach is to only show metrics we can reliably calculate from DB queries (counts, timestamps) and defer expensive operations (reading all files for confidence scores) to v2. This keeps response time under 2ms.

reason: Intent required: No intent token provided

args_preview.content:
## Session Learnings

### Technical
- When restarting uvicorn server on Windows, old processes may persist even after taskkill. Use PowerShell's `Stop-Process -Force` for reliable process termination. Verify port is free with netstat before starting new server - multiple processes can bind to same port on different interfaces (0.0.0.0 vs 127.0.0.1).
- FastAPI router changes require full server restart even with --reload flag if the router file is new. Clear __pycache__ and kill all Python processes to ensure clean state.

### Process
- For Duro Dashboard Insights feature: v1 approach is to only show metrics we can reliably calculate from DB queries (counts, timestamps) and defer expensive operations (reading all files for confidence scores) to v2. This keeps response time under 2ms.

## Completed Tasks
- Implemented Proactive Insights panel for Duro Dashboard (committed 18663b0, pushed to origin/master)

args_preview.learning: When FastAPI routes have both parameterized paths (e.g., /items/{id}) and specific paths (e.g., /items/stats), the specific paths must be defined BEFORE the parameterized path in the router. Otherwise the parameterized route will match first and treat "stats" as an ID.

Duro artifact JSON files store their data in a nested structure: content.data contains the actual fields (symptom, cause, fix, etc.), not content directly. When building APIs that read these files, extract from content.get("data", {}).

args_preview.outcome: Fixed incidents.py router to extract RCA fields from nested content.data structure instead of content directly. Reordered routes so /incidents/stats/summary and /incidents/patterns come before /incidents/{incident_id}. Committed and pushed to origin/master.

args_preview.actual_cause: Both remove_unused_imports and sort_imports don't properly handle multi-line imports. They read node.lineno but not node.end_lineno, causing partial line replacements that corrupt the import block.
args_preview.first_bad_boundary: code_refactor.py:remove_unused_imports and sort_imports functions - they replace lines[start_line-1:end_line] but don't properly calculate end_line for multi-line imports
args_preview.fix: Disabled fix operations by setting SAFE_FIX_OPERATIONS = []. Moved remove_unused_imports and sort_imports to UNSAFE_FIX_OPERATIONS with bug notes. Later fixed properly with AST-based DeadCodeFinder in commit dadcc6f.
args_preview.prevention: Before enabling auto-refactoring tools, test on codebases with: 1) multi-line imports, 2) parenthesized imports, 3) imports with comments. Add specific unit tests for these cases.
repro_steps:
Project has files with multi-line imports like: from X import (
    A,
    B,
)
args_preview.symptom: --fix mode in code_pipeline corrupted Python files, causing SyntaxError in 10+ files
args_preview.why_not_caught: No unit tests for multi-line import edge cases. Manual testing used simple single-line imports only.

args_preview.actual_cause: Both remove_unused_imports and sort_imports don't properly handle multi-line imports. They read node.lineno but not node.end_lineno, causing partial line replacements that corrupt the import block.

args_preview.context: TecArc agency website project - user requested comparison of code-first vs design-first approaches
args_preview.decision: Always follow the design workflow: Style guide → Moodboard/Direction exploration → Mockups with assets → User approval → Implementation. Never jump straight to code.
args_preview.rationale: Jumping straight to code produces generic, forgettable designs. Following the design-first workflow with style guides, multiple directions, and proper mockups produces distinctive, memorable work with the "wow factor". The comparison between Direction A/B (generic) and Direction C (cosmic futurism) proved this - proper workflow yields better creative output.

args_preview.task_description: Create a new rule about always following design workflow

args_preview.learning: Pencil design workflow for posters: Use get_style_guide_tags → get_style_guide for creative direction, then batch_design with I() for structure, G() for AI images, and U() for property fixes. Copy operations (C) with positionDirection/positionPadding efficiently duplicate and position frames. For variations, customize copies with different colors, text, and new G() image prompts.

Character card design pattern in Pencil: Create container frame with horizontal layout, then individual cards with vertical layout containing: circular image frame (cornerRadius = half of width/height), name text, and role/subtitle text. Use signature colors for each character's card background with lighter tint for subtitle text.

args_preview.claim: Duro competitive analysis (Feb 2026): Analyzed 60+ products across 5 categories. Direct competitors: Mem0 ($24M funding, AWS partner), Zep (temporal graphs, enterprise), Letta (MemGPT), Khoj (second brain). Duro's unique moat: (1) Structured memory types (facts/decisions/episodes/evaluations/skills), (2) Decision validation loops, (3) Reputation-based autonomy, (4) 48-hour debug gate, (5) Confidence decay+reinforcement, (6) Local-first full stack. No competitor combines all these. Closest threat: Mem0 (memory-only, no orchestration/learning).
args_preview.snippet: HIGH THREAT: Mem0 (memory layer, $24M), Zep (temporal graphs), Claude Memory (native). MEDIUM: Khoj, Letta, LangGraph. Duro unique features: episode/evaluation tracking, decision validation, reputation autonomy, debug gates, local-first. Market gap: no product combines orchestration + structured learning + local-first.

args_preview.decision: Duro competitive positioning: Focus on learning loops and local-first as primary differentiators against Mem0/Zep
args_preview.rationale: Mem0 and Zep have memory but not learning. They store facts but don't track decisions, validate outcomes, or compound intelligence. Duro's episode→evaluation→skill_stats loop is unique. Local-first ownership is additional moat against cloud-dependent competitors.

args_preview.outcome: Identified unique Duro moat: structured learning (episodes/evaluations/decisions), reputation-based autonomy, debug gates, local-first. Top threats: Mem0 ($24M, AWS), Zep (temporal), Claude Memory. No competitor combines orchestration + learning + local-first. Strategic recommendation: position on learning loops and local ownership.
args_preview.task: Comprehensive Duro competitive analysis - 5 parallel research agents analyzing 60+ products

Duro's unique moat identified: No competitor combines (1) structured memory types (facts/decisions/episodes/evaluations), (2) decision validation loops, (3) reputation-based autonomy, (4) 48-hour debug gates, (5) confidence decay+reinforcement, (6) local-first full stack. Closest threats: Mem0 ($24M, memory-only), Zep (temporal graphs, cloud-only), Khoj (knowledge retrieval only).

Memory persistence is now "table stakes" in AI tools (2026) - GitHub Copilot, Cursor, Claude Code, Windsurf all have persistent memory features. The differentiation is now in structured learning (episodes, evaluations, decision validation) not just storage.

Open source only with services (harder to monetize)
args_preview.decision: Duro business model: Bottoms-up B2B - personal tool for developers, sell team licenses to companies
args_preview.rationale: Developer adopts personally, loves it, brings to work, company pays. Proven model (Slack, Notion, Figma). Lower CAC than enterprise sales, builds organic advocacy. Realistic path to $50-100K ARR Year 1 while bootstrapping.

args_preview.decision: Duro pricing: Free / $19 Pro / $29 Team / Custom Enterprise
args_preview.rationale: $19 Pro is impulse buy for developers. $29 Team undercuts Copilot Business + memory tool combined. Both under expense report threshold ($50). Free tier drives adoption, Pro proves willingness to pay, Team is real business.

args_preview.claim: Duro business model document saved at ~/.agent/memory/docs/duro-business-model-2026-02.md - bottoms-up B2B strategy with Free/$19 Pro/$29 Team pricing, 6-month roadmap, and realistic $50-100K Year 1 ARR projection.

args_preview.result_summary: Explored Duro as enterprise product, refined to bottoms-up B2B model. Defined pricing (Free/$19/$29/Custom), 6-month roadmap, target customers, and realistic Year 1 projections. Saved business model document.

args_preview.learning: Builder's Compass framework maps directly to Duro features: Memory (facts/episodes/decisions), Verification (validation loops/evaluations), Orchestration (MCP/autonomy), Domain Expertise (skills/rules). This creates philosophy-led positioning that competitors can't copy - "you can clone features, you can't clone identity."

Philosophy-led GTM builds movements, not just user bases. Instead of "How to add memory to AI agents" write about "Why the best AI builders focus on verification, not generation." Attracts believers who become advocates.

Tagline evolution: "Memory for AI agents" (technical) → "How builders verify, remember, and compose" (philosophy) → "AI generates. Builders verify. Duro remembers." (punchy). Philosophy positioning justifies pricing better than features alone.

args_preview.learning: Cloud sync is a trap for devtools monetization. It's easy to explain but not what companies pay for. Companies pay for trust (provenance, audit) and control (ACL, review flows). Cloud sync should be positioned as "seatbelt, not engine."

"Trust converts" - In bottoms-up B2B, developers buy features but managers buy trust. When pitching Team plans, emphasize control + audit (what managers care about), not shared features (what developers care about).

The real moat for devtools isn't the data model or features (copyable). The defensible moat is workflow integration + governance habits + integration stickiness. Once teams build processes around your tool, switching is painful.

Every devtool needs a "moment of wow" - one demo that makes people go "holy hell." Without this emotional hook, you're just another tool in a sea of tools. For Duro: agent fails → Duro shows past decision → agent self-corrects with provenance.

args_preview.outcome: Created detailed competitive analysis covering memory systems, orchestration frameworks, PKM+AI, local-first assistants, and coding assistants. Identified Duro's unique position: only product combining structured learning + local-first + reputation autonomy.
args_preview.task: Conducted comprehensive Duro competitive analysis with 5 parallel research agents (60+ products)

args_preview.outcome: Created business model: Free/$19 Pro/$39 Team/Enterprise. Key insight: "Trust converts" - provenance and audit drive purchases, not features. Reprioritized cloud sync as seatbelt, not engine.
args_preview.task: Developed Duro business model (bottoms-up B2B)

args_preview.outcome: Created synthesis document. Core insight: "Duro IS the Builder's Compass made tangible." Tagline: "AI generates. Builders verify. Duro remembers."
args_preview.task: Synthesized Builder's Compass with Duro product positioning

args_preview.outcome: Incorporated sharp feedback: trust features before cloud sync, $39 Team pricing, moat is workflow not data model, need "moment of wow" demo. Updated priorities and 6-month plan.
args_preview.task: Updated business model with GTM feedback (v2)

args_preview.outcome: Created ApeNIG/duro-docs (private) with competitive analysis, business model v2, and Builder's Compass synthesis. Reverted DAI repo to remove docs folder.
args_preview.task: Created duro-docs private GitHub repo

alternatives: Original model: cloud sync as first paid feature at $29 Team
args_preview.decision: Duro business model v2: Trust features (provenance, audit, inspect) before cloud sync. Team pricing at $39. First priority is "moment of wow" demo.
args_preview.rationale: GTM feedback revealed cloud sync is a trap (not what companies pay for), trust converts (managers buy control/audit), and moat is workflow habits not data model. Need emotional hook demo to stand out.

args_preview.learning: Philosophy-led positioning needs grounding: every big claim must collapse into a screenshot, workflow, or measurable outcome. "Philosophy on top, concrete underneath."
Operationalize philosophy into product spec: each pillar needs a Metric, Loop, Default Workflow, and Visible Artifact. This turns positioning into roadmap.

The Builder's Compass Score concept: Verification coverage, Staleness index, Decision closure rate, Skill reuse rate, Tool reliability. People love brutal scoreboards - this becomes dashboard AND sales wedge.
The killer loop for Duro: Decision → Outcome → Evaluation → Skill/Rule Update. Ship this first - it's compounding intelligence in the raw. Don't boil the philosophy ocean.

args_preview.outcome: Added metrics/loops/workflows/artifacts per pillar, Builder's Compass Score dashboard concept, killer loop identification, risks section, tightened positioning (humble > self-important), One Sentence + One Screenshot rule.
args_preview.task: Updated Builder's Compass synthesis with operational feedback (v2)
